description.plain:
A Tribe Called Quest is to Hip Hop what Pink Floyd is to Rock ‘n’ Roll. With humble beginnings in Queens, New York, the group blossomed from the friendship of Jonathan Davis (Q-Tip) and Malik Taylor (Phife Dawg).  Along with acts like Jungle Brothers and De La Soul—their comrades in the Native Tongues rap collective—they vitalized East Coast Hip Hop, setting the stage for the rise of mainstream and alternative hip hop alike.



Their style, a synthesis of avant-garde production and authentic lyricism, paved the way for the conscious and jazz rap movements. Alongside other upbeat artists like Digable Planets, Us3, and Guru, ATCQ opened up the world of afrocentrism to a wider audience.

  


MEMBERS

Q-Tip –  MC/producer

Phife Dawg – MC

Ali Shaheed Muhammad – DJ/producer

Jarobi – MC/chef




Following appearances from Q-Tip on the debut albums of De La Soul (3 Feet High and Rising’s “Buddy”) and the Jungle Brothers (Straight Out the Jungle’s “The Promo” and “Black is Black”), Tribe’s debut album People’s Instinctive Travels and the Paths of Rhythm was released in 1990. It featured the hit singles “Bonita Applebum,” “Can I Kick It?,” and “I Left My Wallet in El Segundo.” Their next two albums—1991’s The Low End Theory (featuring the hits “Check the Rhime” and the classic posse cut “Scenario”) and 1993’s Midnight Marauders (featuring the hits “Award Tour” and “Electric Relaxation”)—are considered two of the greatest hip-hop albums of all-time.

Their 1996 album Beats, Rhymes, and Life debuted at #1 on the Billboard 200 and was nominated for a Grammy in the Best Rap Album category. Their fifth album, 1998’s The Love Movement, featured the hit “Find a Way” but would be their last album for years as Q-Tip and Phife focused on their solo careers.

Phife Dawg died March 22, 2016 as a result of complications from diabetes. Before Phife’s passing, the group reunited on The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon to perform “Can I Kick It?” on November 13, 2015 in a celebration of their debut album’s 25th anniversary. They went on to record what would become the group’s final album, We Got It From Here…Thank You 4 Your Service, which was released on November 11, 2016. It became their second album to debut at #1 on the Billboard 200 chart.

songs.full_title: We the People.... by A Tribe Called Quest
songs.title: We the People....

description.plain:
One of the more political songs on We Got it From Here… Thank You 4 Your Service, “We The People…” illuminates the problems in modern America, including police brutality, racial and religious discrimination, threats of deportation, and a lack of equality for women.

The political overtones of this song reference the preamble to the US Constitution which famously starts with “We the People”.

songs.lyrics:
[Verse 1: Q-Tip]
We don't believe you 'cause we the people
Are still here in the rear, ayo, we don't need you
You in the killing-off-good-young-nigga mood
When we get hungry we eat the same fucking food
The ramen noodle
Your simple voodoo is so maniacal, we're liable to pull a juju
The irony is that this bad bitch in my lap
She don't love me, she make money, she don't study that
She gon' give it to me, ain't gon' tell me run it back
She gon' take the brain to wetter plains, she spit on that
The doors have signs with, don't try to rhyme with
VH1 has a show that you can waste your time with
Guilty pleasures take the edge off reality
And for a salary I'd probably do that shit sporadically
The OG Gucci boots are smitten with iguanas
The IRS piranha see a nigga gettin' commas
Niggas in the hood living in a fishbowl
Gentrify here, now it's not a shit hole
Trendsetter, I know, my shit's cold
Ain't settling because I ain't so bold but ay

[Hook: Q-Tip]
All you Black folks, you must go
All you Mexicans, you must go
And all you poor folks, you must go
Muslims and gays, boy, we hate your ways
So all you bad folks, you must go

[Bridge: Phife Dawg & Q-Tip]
The fog and the smog of news media that logs
False narratives of Gods that came up against the odds
We're not just nigga rappers with the bars
It's kismet that we're cosmic with the stars

[Verse 2: Phife Dawg]
You bastards overlooking street art
Better yet, street smarts but you keep us off the charts
So motherfuck your numbers and your statisticians
Fuck y'all know about true competition?
That's like a AL pitcher on deck talking about he hittin'
The only one who's hitting are the ones that's currently spittin'
We got your missy smitten rubbing on her little kitten
Dreaming of a world that's equal for women with no division
Boy, I tell you that's vision
Like Tony Romo when he hitting Witten
The Tribe be the best in they division
Shaheed Muhammad cut it with precision
Who can come back years later, still hit the shot?
Still them tryna move we off the fucking block
Babylon, bloodclaat
Two pon yuh headtop

[Hook: Q-Tip]
All you Black folks, you must go
All you Mexicans, you must go
And all you poor folks, you must go

songs.full_title: Electric Relaxation by A Tribe Called Quest
songs.title: Electric Relaxation

description.plain:
The second single from Midnight Marauders finds the Tribe mixing the back-and-forth from “Check the Rhime” with the smoothness and similar subject matter of “Bonita Applebum.” Tip delivers his “street poetry” alongside Phife’s punchlines over a sample from Ronnie Foster’s “Mystic Brew.” In a 2013 interview with XXL, Phife briefly detailed the making of the track:

I came home from some type of trip and I walked in the kitchen, and you know, [Q-Tip]’s in the basement and you could hear the music coming up, and all I heard was that. I didn’t even say hello to my grandmother or whoever was in the house, I was just like, “Hold on!” and went downstairs. “Yo, what the hell is that?!” He was like, “Yo, that shit is crazy, right?” And it just became what it is now  […] On that record, he wrote my lines and I wrote his—actually, we wrote our own lines, and when we recorded, we traded. That’s why the whole back and forth, you know what I mean?

This track peaked at number 2 on Billboard’s Hot Dance Music/Maxi-Singles chart and it was also used as the theme song for the first two seasons of The Wayans Bros. The song has been included on many lists of hip-hop’s greatest songs and it has been sampled or referenced by a number of artists such as Kanye West and BadBadNotGood among others.

songs.title_with_featured: Scenario (Ft. Leaders of the New School)

description.plain:
Featuring Leaders of the New School, “Scenario” is one of the most celebrated posse cuts of all-time and the second one featured on the group’s second LP The Low End Theory, aside from “Show Business”. The song has also been attributed for the break-out of Leaders of the New School member Busta Rhymes for his impressive verse.

The song’s prominence in hip-hop even made the remixed version a well-liked song by fans. The remixed version was included on the B-Side of the 12" single release, as well as limited edition release of the group’s 1998 album The Love Movement.

Time included the song on it’s list of “All-Time 100 Songs.”

The group’s 1992 live performance on the Arsenio Hall Show helped the song gain popularity.

songs.lyrics:
[Chorus: All]
Here we go, yo, here we go, yo
So what, so what, so what's the scenario?
Here we go, yo, here we go, yo
So what, so what, so what's the scenario?

[Verse 1: Phife Dawg & All]
Ayo, Bo knows this (What?) And Bo knows that (What?)
But Bo don't know jack, 'cause Bo can't rap
Well, what do you know? The Di-Dawg is first up to bat
No batteries included and no strings attached
No holds barred, no time for move-fakin'
Gots to get the loot so I can bring home the bacon
Brothers front, they say the Tribe can't flow
But we've been known to do the impossible like Broadway Joe, so
Sleep if you want, Nytol will help you get your Zs, troop
But here's the real scoop
I'm all that and then some, short, dark, and handsome
Bust a nut inside your eye to show you where I come from
I'm vexed, fuming, I've had it up to here
My days of paying dues are over, acknowledge me as in there
(Yeah!) Head for the border, go get a taco
Watch me wreck it from the jump street, meaning from the get-go
Sit back, relax, and let yourself go
Don't sweat what you heard, but act like you know

[Verse 2: Charlie Brown & All]
Yes, yes, y'all, (Yes, y'all!)
Who got the vibe? It's the Tribe, y'all (Tribe, y'all!)
Real live, y'all (Live, y'all!)
Inside, outside, come around
(Who's that?) Brown!
So, may I say, call me Charlie
The word is the herb and I'm deep like Bob Marley
Lay back on the payback, evolve, rotate the gates (Contact!)
Can I get a hit? (Hit!) Boom, bip
With a brother named Tip, and we're ready to flip
East coast stomping, ripping, and romping
New York, North Cak-a-laka, and Compton
Checka-checka-check it out
The loops for the troops, more bounce to the ounce
And wow-how-now-wow, how now, Brown cow?
We're ill 'til the skill gets down
For the flex, next, it's the textbook, old to the new
But the rest are doo-doo
From radio, to the video, to Arsenio
Tell me, yo; what's the scenario?

[Verse 3: Dinco D & All]
(True blue!) Scooby Doo, whoopie doo
Scenarios, radios, rates more than four
Scores for the s'mores that smother dance floors
Now I go for mine, shades of sea shore
Ship-shape, crushed grapes, apes that play tapes
Papes make drakes baked for the wakes
Of an (L-ah-!), an (-eader!), simply just a leader
Base in the space means peace, see ya later
Later (Later!) later, alligator
Pop blows the weasel and the urge to inflate her
So, yo, the D, what! The O
Incorporated I-N-C into a flow
Funk flipped, flat back, first this, foul, fight, fight, fight
Laugh, yo, how'd that sound? (Ooh!)

[Verse 4: Q-Tip, Busta Rhymes, & All]
It's a Leader-Quest mission and we got the goods here (Here!)
Never on the left 'cause my right's my good ear (Ear!)
I could give a damn about a ill subliminal
Stay away from crime so I ain't no (criminal!)
I love my young nation, groovy sensation
No time for hibernation, only elation
Don't ever try to test the water, little kid
Yo, Mr. Busta Rhymes, tell him what I did—
—I heard you rushed and rushed (and attacked!)
Then they rebuked and you (had to smack!)
Causing rambunction throughout the sphere
Raise the levels of the boom inside the ear—
—You know I did it
So don't violate or you'll get violated
The hip-hop sound is well agitated
Won't ever waste no time on a played out ego
So here's Busta Rhymes with the scenario:

[Verse 5: Busta Rhymes & All]
Watch; as I combine all the juice from the mind
Heel up, wheel up, bring it back, come, rewind
Powerful impact (Boom!) from the cannon!
Not bragging, tryna read my mind, just imagine
Vo-cab-u-lary's necessary
When diggin' into my library
Oh, my gosh! Oh, my gosh!
Eating Ital Stew like the one Peter Tosh
Unh! Unh! Unh! All over the track, man
Unh, pardon me, unh! As I come back!
As I did it, yo, I had to beg your pardon
When I travel through the town I roll with the squadron
Rawr! Rawr! Like a dungeon dragon
Change your little drawers 'cause your pants were saggin'
Try to step to this, I will twist you in a turban
And have you smelling rank like some old, stale urine
Chickity Choco, the chocolate chicken
The rear cock diesel, buttcheeks, they were kicking
Yo, bust it out before the Busta bust another rhyme
The rhythm is in sync (Unh!) the rhymes are on time (Time!)
Rippin' up the sound just like Horatio
Observe the vibe and check out the scenario
Yeah, my man, mothafucka!

[Chorus (Extended): All]
Here we go, yo, here we go, yo
So what, so what, so what's the scenario?
Here we go, yo, here we go, yo
So what, so what, so what's the scenario?
Here we go, yo, here we go, yo
So what, so what, so what's the scenario?
Here we go, yo, here we go, yo
So what, so what, so what's the scenario?

songs.full_title: Can I Kick It? by A Tribe Called Quest
songs.title: Can I Kick It?

description.plain:
“Can I Kick It?” was the third single from A Tribe Called Quest’s debut album People’s Instinctive Travels and the Paths of Rhythm.

The original version contains samples from Lou Reed’s 1972 classic “Walk on the Wild Side,” “Spinning Wheel” by Dr. Lonnie Smith and “Sunshower" by ‘70s pop group Dr. Buzzard’s Original Savannah Band.The numerous remixes sample everything from Baby Huey to Ian Dury.



Peep the J Cole’s Remix to this classic for the 25th anniversary of their debut album. The group also made their first television appearance together in over 15 years on The Tonight Show with Jimmy Fallon.

[Chorus: Q-Tip]
Can I kick it? (Yes, you can!)

[Verse 1: Q-Tip]
Can I kick it? To all the people who can Quest like A Tribe does
Before this, did you really know what live was?
Comprehend to the track, for it's why cuz
Gettin measures on the tip of the vibers
Rock and roll to the beat of the funk fuzz
Wipe your feet really good on the rhythm rug
If you feel the urge to freak, do the jitterbug
Come and spread your arms if you really need a hug
Afrocentric living is a big shrug
A life filled with fun that's what I love
A lower plateau is what we're above
If you diss us, we won't even think of
Will Nipper the doggy give a big shove?

Like a box of positives it's a plus, love
As the Tribe flies high like a dove
(Can I kick it?)

[Chorus: Phife Dawg]

You'll be doing us a really big favor
Boy this track really has a lot of flavor
When it comes to rhythms, Quest is your savior
Follow us for the funky behavior
Make a note on the rhythm we gave ya
Feel free, drop your pants, check your ha-ir

I instruct you to be the obeyer

Doesn't matter if you're minor or major
Yes, the Tribe of the game we're the player

(Can I kick it?)

songs.full_title: Check the Rhime by A Tribe Called Quest
songs.title: Check the Rhime

description.plain:
“Check the Rhime” is the quintessential and most celebrated hip-hop song for call-and-response rhyme cipher. Q-Tip and Phife Dawg celebrate their middle-class roots from Queens, with Phife delivering one of his most inspired verses.

“Check The Rhime” was ranked number 29 on VH1’s 100 Greatest Songs of Hip Hop.

The song was released as a single on September 6, 1991 with B-side “Skypager”.

songs.full_title: Buggin' Out by A Tribe Called Quest
songs.title: Buggin’ Out

description.plain:
“Buggin' Out” is attributed as the song responsible for the emergence of Phife Dawg as a notable emcee rapper, who trades verses with Q-Tip.

The song exudes a playful enthusiasm over the jazzy bassline and the iconic “boom-thack” sounding beat.

The song’s music video has has been praised as groundbreaking aesthetically and on a conceptual level. It set a new bar and influenced how hip-hop music videos would be made in the industry by future video directors such as Hype Williams. The music video included songs “Buggin' Out” and “Jazz (We’ve Got).”

songs.full_title: Bonita Applebum by A Tribe Called Quest
songs.title: Bonita Applebum

description.plain:
“Bonita Applebum” is the second single off A Tribe Called Quest’s debut album People’s Instinctive Travels and the Paths of Rhythm (1990). It was a popular song in its time and has since become a hip-hop classic. The song, which is rumored to be based on an actual girl from ATCQ’s high school, is a confession of love from Q-Tip to a girl who happens to have a rather sizable posterior.

Samples include “Mathar” by The Dave Pike Set, “Daylight” by RAMP, “Memory Band” by Rotary Connection, and “Fool Yourself” by Little Feat.

Also see the excellent Hootie Mix

songs.full_title: Jazz (We've Got) by A Tribe Called Quest
songs.title: Jazz (We’ve Got)

description.plain:
“Jazz (We’ve Got)” is Jazz rap at its finest. Q-Tip and Phife Dawg both deliver some tripped out verses.

The production features a mellow, snare-heavy beat and a haunting piano loop, as well as a very soulful, jazzy soprano saxaphone sample.

Although not the most popular, “Jazz (We’ve Got)” was complemented by a classic, absurd music video that gets a nod from many hardcore hip hop fans. The music video combined the songs “Jazz (We’ve Got)” and “Buggin' Out,” officially titled “Jazz (We’ve Got) Buggin' Out.”

songs.full_title: The Space Program by A Tribe Called Quest
songs.title: The Space Program

description.plain:
“The Space Program” is the first song off ATCQ’s sixth and final studio album We Got It from Here… Thank You 4 Your Service. The song sets the tone for the rest of the politically-driven project.

Verses from members Q-Tip, Jarobi, and the late Phife Dawg illustrate the struggles and harsh reality that the African American community continues to face.  Lyrics form a call-to-action as the group cites the oppression and ostracization of minorities.

On November 12, 2016, Tribe performed this track on Saturday Night Live and invited Busta Rhymes and Consequence to join them on the outro.

In the beginning of March 2018, Tribe teased a trailer for their “last video” which would late premiere on June 28th of the same year.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qTrqmNieVKI

On March 29, 2018, Tribe released their music video for “The Space Program”, exclusively through Apple Music. The 8 minute visual, directed by Warren Fu, features a host of past collaborators and long time friends of Tribe, performing Phife Dawg’s closing chorus, including; Consequence, Erykah Badu, Vince Staples, Pharrell Williams, Common, Alicia Keys, Rosario Dawson, Questlove and more.

songs.full_title: Award Tour by A Tribe Called Quest (Ft. Trugoy the Dove)
songs.title: Award Tour

description.plain:
“Award Tour” was the lead single from Tribe’s third album, Midnight Marauders. Over a sample of Weldon Irvine’s “We Gettin' Down” and a chorus interpolating lines from Malcolm McLaren’s “Hobo Scratch,” Tip and Phife appear to be celebrating their worldwide success they were achieving with their critically acclaimed sophomore album, The Low End Theory. They also bring in fellow Native Tongues member Trugoy the Dove from De La Soul to perform the hook, and he appears in the music video mysteriously holding his right eye.

Q-Tip talked to Vibe magazine about the song’s production:

I love the drums on ‘Award Tour.’ And then there’s the sample I used from Jade’s ‘Don’t Walk Away.’ It’s all about that bassline. I just wanted to flip it, so I went through some more records and I got that Rhodes to counter the melody in the bassline. I wanted some drums that would smack that shit out the park.

The single topped Billboard’s Hot Dance Music/Maxi-Singles Sales chart, while peaking at #7 on the Hot Rap Songs chart and #47 on the Billboard Hot 100, making it their most successful single.

songs.full_title: Dis Generation by A Tribe Called Quest (Ft. Busta Rhymes)
songs.title: Dis Generation

description.plain:
“Dis Generation” is an ode to the new generation of hip-hop. Since ATCQ was a huge influence due to their 90’s classic records like Midnight Marauders and The Low End Theory, they spend this track praising the MC’s who have perpetuated the realness that they once conveyed.

The group shouts out such new generation rappers as Joey Bada$$, Earl Sweatshirt, Kendrick Lamar and J. Cole.

The track samples “Ruido de Magia” by Argentinian band Invisible. Its music video debuted on March 30, 2017.

description.plain:
“Conrad Tokyo” is A Tribe Called Quest’s reflection on the economical and political situation of the United States in the 2010’s, including the general acceptance of political figures such as Donald Trump.

The track is part of the long awaited final album We Got It From Here… Thank You 4 Your Service and features a guest appearance of Kendrick Lamar.

songs.full_title: Excursions by A Tribe Called Quest
songs.title: Excursions

description.plain:
“Excursions” is a song that sets the theme for the rest of the record, and arguably the group’s career. Within the song’s first few lines, Q-Tip recalls words from his father who likened the improvisational nature of jazz’s bebop to hip-hop’s freedom filled sonic structure.

The song sets the central thesis for the album of afrocentric content delivered with witty lyricisim over minimalistic jazz grooves.

songs.full_title: Kids... by A Tribe Called Quest (Ft. André 3000)
songs.title: Kids...

description.plain:
The sixth track off of A Tribe Called Quest’s sixth and final studio album, 2016’s politically-driven We got it from Here… Thank You 4 Your service, “Kids…” is a synth-laden track that touches on the angst and confusion found in the younger generations.

Aside from Q-Tip, the song features André 3000, who was a former member of OutKast and was heavily inspired by Tribe’s work. In a moving tribute to one of Tribe’s members, Phife Dawg, who passed away in 2016, André stated:

When we got our deal, we rapped for Rico Wade in the parking lot. The only thing me and Big had was “Scenario” on cassette and we rapped for days, just going. And in high school, my first rap name was Jhaz because of these niggas. It was J-H-A-Z; I don’t know how I was thinking I was spelling that shit. Because of “Jazz (We’ve Got).” We would sit in high school and be like, ‘Man, we love them.’ … Influence. Influence is really important. In the same way that we’re here because of you all, and it’s totally true.

Both Kast and Tribe planned on creating a joint album before Phife’s untimely death. André expressed his remorse for not being able to finish the album, explaining:

Please people, don’t let the time go by because you never know. That’s one of the biggest things that I regret now. For whatever reason, we didn’t do it. It was on our plate and we let it go for our own personal reasons or whatever.

description.plain:
Tribe’s main single off their fifth The Love Movement (1998), produced by the brilliant J-Dilla alongside Q-Tip and Ali Shaheed Muhammad.

Tip and Phife are complaining about girls teasing  them. They aren’t sure if they should come on harder or just “sit-out”.

Samples Towa Tei feat. Bebel Gilberto
“Technova (La Em Copacabana)” (1995) and  “Got ‘Til It’s Gone” by Janet Jackson feat. Q-Tip and Joni Mitchell (1997).

body.plain:
Tribe’s main single off their fifth The Love Movement (1998), produced by the brilliant J-Dilla alongside Q-Tip and Ali Shaheed Muhammad.

Tip and Phife are complaining about girls teasing  them. They aren’t sure if they should come on harder or just “sit-out”.

Samples Towa Tei feat. Bebel Gilberto
“Technova (La Em Copacabana)” (1995) and  “Got ‘Til It’s Gone” by Janet Jackson feat. Q-Tip and Joni Mitchell (1997).

songs.full_title: Butter by A Tribe Called Quest
songs.title: Butter

description.plain:
“Butter” is Phife Dawg’s semi-autobiographical lyrical showcase that addresses girl problems. Phife contrasts his personal experiences with the girls in high school to handling the same girls later in life as a smooth “mack.” At the root of Phife’s girl problems is the difficulty to distinguish love from being played.

The song features minimalistic production behind a solid drum beat sampled from Chuck Jackson’s 1968 rendition of “I Like Everything About You.”

During the album’s conception, Phife Dawg insisted that this song be his solo track on the album, due to his shortage of features on the group’s debut album. The original version was to include a verse from Q-Tip.

[Intro: Q-Tip]

songs.full_title: Whateva Will Be by A Tribe Called Quest (Ft. Consequence)
songs.title: Whateva Will Be

description.plain:
“Whateva Will Be” talks about the inevitability of the social issues that black people face. ATCQ notes that only the strongest with prevail against the world’s obstacles.

The track carries a dark theme, with each member portraying their race as inferior, longing for hope in a world with odds stacked against them.

songs.full_title: The Killing Season by A Tribe Called Quest (Ft. Consequence, Kanye West & Talib Kweli)
songs.title: The Killing Season
songs.title_with_featured: The Killing Season (Ft. Consequence, Kanye West & Talib Kweli)

description.plain:
“The Killing Season” features frequent ATCQ collaborator Consequence, hip hop veteran Talib Kweli and Kanye West, himself a product of ATCQ’s influence.

The song’s lyrics use repeated mentions of soldiers, veterans, war and the military as a means of describing injustices faced by blacks in America. Specific references are made to killings of black political leaders, police brutality and the mistreatment of army veterans.

songs.full_title: Melatonin by A Tribe Called Quest (Ft. Marsha Ambrosius & YEBBA)
songs.title: Melatonin

description.plain:
“Melatonin” highlights the struggles of daily modern life.  Melatonin is a natural hormone that one can get as an over-the-counter supplement to help with sleep.

Abbey Smith assists Q-Tip in telling how the drug can be used to help calm the thoughts that flood ones mind, particularly at night.

songs.full_title: Steve Biko (Stir it Up) by A Tribe Called Quest
songs.title: Steve Biko (Stir it Up)

description.plain:
The first track off of Tribe’s critically acclaimed Midnight Marauders, where the group introduces themselves and their uplifting lyrics.
Also, the song is named after revolutionary anti-apartheid activist, Steve Biko, notable in the anti-colonialism and anti-oppression community worldwide.

description.plain: “Movin Backwards” is ATCQ’s explanation of the path of either “success” or “failure.” The track, featuring Anderson .Paak, explains the themes of feeling lost, being remembered, and gaining success without losing your qualities over time.

songs.full_title: Enough!! by A Tribe Called Quest
songs.title: Enough!!

description.plain:
“Enough!!” is a track from A Tribe Called Quest’s We got it from Here… Thank You 4 Your service album.

Utilizing several “unresolved” chords, the sonically inquisitive song delves into the challenge of balancing a romantic relationship with a passion for one’s profession, specifically being a professional musician. Many of the lines could apply to romantic love or also passion for the music.

The track includes subtle contributions from Internet lead singer Syd, as well as bits of their hit hip-hop love song “Bonita Applebaum” cut into the track by DJ Scratch.

songs.full_title: 8 Million Stories by A Tribe Called Quest
songs.title: 8 Million Stories

description.plain:
“8 Million Stories” is about having the ultimate bad day. From waking up, going on dates, to helping friends, Phife seems to run into trouble everywhere he goes. Phife knows that he’s not the only one who has a bad day though. The thousands of floors (stories) of project housing filled with millions of people are rife with stories and tales about what could have been.



The Phife Diggy solo joint is one of only two non self-produced tracks on the album. Production is handled by Skeff Anselm (he gets props too!).

Samples “Bettina” by Bola Sete and “Over the Rainbow” by The Ohio Players.

Jay-Z payed homage to this iconic song in his ode to New York, “Empire State Of Mind”, with this line.

The thousands of floors (stories) of project housing filled with millions of people are rife with stories and tales about what could have been.



The Phife Diggy solo joint is one of only two non self-produced tracks on the album. Production is handled by Skeff Anselm (he gets props too!).

Samples “Bettina” by Bola Sete and “Over the Rainbow” by The Ohio Players.

Jay-Z payed homage to this iconic song in his ode to New York, “Empire State Of Mind”, with this line.

songs.full_title: Mobius by A Tribe Called Quest (Ft. Busta Rhymes & Consequence)
songs.title: Mobius

description.plain:
Named after the 19th century German scientist August Möbius and his intriguing geometric discovery, “Mobius” features Consequence’s casual conversation-like flow paired with Busta Rhyme’s boastful gusto. The track explores topics ranging from the everyday concerns of a star artist, to the Illuminati conspiracy, the media, and echoes of a hardcore street lifestyle.


And now it’s more real than it is for any other star/ And that’s enough to have you tearing up the mini-bar […]

They say Illuminati and other ordeals is how lawyer got me to avoid a raw deal […]

I pull the gat up, whip the shit, cook the batter/ When I pull up on niggas, even your momma gon scatter


The verses are laid out over instrumental production that seems to mimic the continuous, winding geometry of the shape that gives this track its name. Note how the outro music is identical to the intro, just like the Mobius strip.

songs.full_title: Verses from the Abstract by A Tribe Called Quest
songs.title: Verses from the Abstract

description.plain:
Q-Tip spits on “Verses from the Abstract” with an unconventional flow, landing in unusual pockets, that seem to work, creating a funky style of rap that has influenced hip hop artists since it’s release. The lyrical content of his signature song seems to emanate from stream-of-conscious thoughts with plenty of shout-outs to prominent rappers of the group’s scene.

The Tribe brought in recording jazz bassist Ron Carter to pull off a jazzy, yet funky bassline for the beat. Q-Tip told New York Times,

We wanted that straight bass sound, and Ron Carter is one of the premier bassists of the century.

The group also had to invite session vocalist Vinia Mojica back to sing on the song’s hook. She appeared in skits on the group’s debut album. After hearing Mojica sing on De La Soul’s 1991 hit, “A Roller Skating Jam Called Saturdays,” Q-Tip was adamant that she sing on the Tribe’s second album. In an interview with Revive Music Mojia recalled,

[De La Soul & A Tribe Called Quest] had a lot of love-hate rivalries […] They always wanted to one up each other. I think that’s why Q-Tip asked me to do something for their album, even though I was on their first album in the snippets in between.

songs.full_title: Black Spasmodic by A Tribe Called Quest
songs.title: Black Spasmodic

description.plain:
“Black Spasmodic” is a highlight of A Tribe Called Quest’s 2016 comeback album We Got It From Here… Thank You 4 Your Service. Consequence handles the hook while Q-Tip and Phife do the intro in tandem.

The first verse belongs to the late Phife Dawg who uses it to express gratitude for the gift of music artistry and that the Tribe has finally reunited. He then shows off his gift by detailing a hilarious story of upstaging a rap crew at their own show, all the while seamlessly shifting in and out of his Patois dialect.

In the second verse, obviously recorded after Phife’s sudden death, Q-Tip finishes the song by memorializing his fallen brother. In the first half, he takes on the rap battle persona he says Phife would have wanted him to and puts in their place rappers who haven’t shown due deference to ATCQ’s legacy. In the second half, he raps in the person of Phife Dawg, communicating what he feels would be Phife’s final wishes.

Overall, the track is a juxtaposition of mourning the loss of Phife while celebrating his greatness and becomes one of many upbeat emotional peaks on the We Got It From Here album.

songs.full_title: What? by A Tribe Called Quest
songs.title: What?

description.plain:
“What?” is a short uptempo song on The Low End Theory solely featuring bars from Q-Tip and no hook at all. The motif is Q-Tip asking a series of questions—some rhetorical, some nonsensical. The lines follow the pattern of starting with “What?”

The sparse track entirely consists of a loop of the Paul Humphrey song called “Uncle Willie’s Dream” (1974). The track’s bouncy momentum culminates into a group shout of “What!!” that leads directly into the album’s crown jewel posse cut, “Scenario.”

songs.full_title: The Infamous Date Rape by A Tribe Called Quest
songs.title: The Infamous Date Rape

description.plain:
“The Infamous Date Rape” is the eighth track on A Tribe Called Quest’s sophomore album, The Low End Theory. The song, notably, covers the crime of date rape which usually involves a person drugging their sex partner during a romantic encounter before raping them when they are rendered semi- or unconscious. It’s also worth mentioning that this occurred to approximately 110 out of 10,000 women during the time that the song released.

Q-Tip and Phife Dawg offer social commentary on this topic as they trade verses throughout the track. The duo covers the topic of rape towards women while also providing casual jokes about sex, in general.

Overall, the content heavily contrasts that of the misogynistic vibes given by most rappers during the late 1980s and 1990s. Chuck D described violent abuse towards women on “Sophisticated Bitch” and Dr. Dre rapped about murdering his partner on “One Less Bitch”.

songs.full_title: I Left My Wallet in El Segundo by A Tribe Called Quest
songs.title: I Left My Wallet in El Segundo
songs.title_with_featured: I Left My Wallet in El Segundo

description.plain:
The song title is a reference to Sanford and Son, a popular television sitcom from the 70s. Fred Sanford, a character from the show, would always mention El Segundo as a joke, like “Godzilla Eats El Segundo!” for example.

Q also tells us this in the movie/documentary Beats, Rhymes & Life: The Travels of A Tribe Called Quest.

El Segundo is a part of LA county in California.

songs.full_title: Luck of Lucien by A Tribe Called Quest (Ft. Papalu)
songs.title: Luck of Lucien

description.plain:
Lucien Revolucien was a French hip hop artist in the 1990s who was also featured on  Afrika Bambaataa’s anti-apartheid anthem. This song is dedicated to Lucien and his efforts as an artist.

“Luck of Lucien” samples “Forty Days” by Billy Brooks (from the 1974 album Windows of the Mind) and Rouget de l’Isle’s “La Marseillaise,” the national anthem of France.

songs.full_title: Georgie Porgie by A Tribe Called Quest (Ft. Brand Nubian)
songs.title: Georgie Porgie

description.plain:
This unreleased oddity is the original version of “Show Business”.

Fortunately for Tribe’s legacy the label flat out rejected the track and everyone had to rewrite their rhymes. Puba bailed in protest and Diamond D stepped in at the last minute. And thus the track we now know as “Show Business” was born.

It is worth noticing that the members of Tribe have changed their opinion on this subject.  On “We the People….”, which was released on 2016, Q-Tip’s hook criticises the homophobia of the alt-right and Trump’s administration. The track defends and unifies oppressed minorities – such as blacks, Mexicans, Muslims, the poor and gays.

annotatable.title: Georgie Porgie

body.plain:
This unreleased oddity is the original version of “Show Business”.

Fortunately for Tribe’s legacy the label flat out rejected the track and everyone had to rewrite their rhymes. Puba bailed in protest and Diamond D stepped in at the last minute. And thus the track we now know as “Show Business” was born.

It is worth noticing that the members of Tribe have changed their opinion on this subject.  On “We the People….”, which was released on 2016, Q-Tip’s hook criticises the homophobia of the alt-right and Trump’s administration. The track defends and unifies oppressed minorities – such as blacks, Mexicans, Muslims, the poor and gays.

songs.full_title: Show Business by A Tribe Called Quest (Ft. Brand Nubian & Diamond D)
songs.title: Show Business
songs.title_with_featured: Show Business (Ft. Brand Nubian & Diamond D)

description.plain:
“Show Business” is a cautionary tale about Industry Rule #4080, a reference introduced later in the album on “Check the Rhime”. The song is the first  posse cut on the album, featuring Lord Jamar and Sadat X of Brand Nubian, as well as Diamond D of D.I.T.C..

“Show Business” is a re-worked version of the group’s 1991 unreleased song, “Georgie Porgie.”

Q-Tip talked about the origin of this song on Brian Coleman’s book, Check the Technique:

As for Brand Nubian, we had a song called “Georgie Porgie” that we did with them. It was about a kid who grew up in the ‘hood and wound up being gay. We played it for the label [Jive] and they felt that it was a little too … strong. So we all decided not to put it on the album. Puba got mad and didn’t want to do another track, so that’s why he’s not on there. We used the same beat.

[Verse 4: Phife Dawg]

The Born Cipher Cipher Master makes me think much faster

My name and discredit my fame
All that shit is game and I don't really give a damn
Eat from the tree of life and throw away the verbal ham

[Verse 6: Diamond D]
Well, excuse me, I gotta add my two cents in
Don't be alarmed, the rhyme was condensed in

description.plain:
The “Part Two” of the title references a radically different version of the song Tribe demoed, with lyrical similarities but a much harder beat. With the smooth nocturnal sounds of this record, it’s not hard to see why Tribe chose to re-style this one.

Samples “Beddie Bey” by Steve Arrington and “Nobody Beats the Biz” by Biz Markie.

songs.full_title: 1nce Again by A Tribe Called Quest (Ft. Tammy Lucas)
songs.title: 1nce Again

description.plain:
“1nce Again” was the group’s first endeavor to cross over into the mainstream R&B market without selling out their traditional sound. With the group’s chemistry being off during the album’s recording sessions, along with the pressures of fame, Q-Tip and Phife-Dawg brought back the feeling of the group’s earlier days by incorporating lines from their hit “Check The Rhime”. The song was a juxtaposition between the group’s traditional sound and the new sound they sought to achieve on the album.

The hook featured stunning vocals from R&B singer Tammy Lucas with a sound that was suitable for mid-90’s hit radio. The verses still retained the traditional Tribe sound with it’s jazzy bassline and hard-hitting drum beat.

“1nce Again” was the first single from the album Beats, Rhymes and Life and was nominated for a Grammy Award for Best Rap Performance by a Duo or Group in 1997.

songs.full_title: Vibes and Stuff by A Tribe Called Quest
songs.title: Vibes and Stuff

description.plain:
As the song title suggests, “Vibes and Stuff” is a laid-back song that features more laconic verses from Q-Tip and Phife Dawg. The song radiates positive vibes that transport the listener to the sunny streets of Queens, NY with plenty of shoutouts all around.

Vibes is also shorthand for a vibraphone, which is one of the instruments used in the beat of the song.

songs.full_title: God Lives Through by A Tribe Called Quest
songs.title: God Lives Through

description.plain:
There’s a whopping 5 samples for this song in total.


The Trumpet hook of the song is from Dig on it by Jimmy McGriff
The other elements like the bass and tempo is from On love by David T. Walker
The elongated shout from many of A Tribe Called Quest songs comes from Gimme some more (not to be confused with the Busta Rhymes song of the same name) by The J.B.’s
The drums are from the song And that’s saying a lot by Christine McVie
The “Oh my God!” sample from the song title of the same name reappears, leading to the name of this song.

songs.full_title: Stressed Out by A Tribe Called Quest (Ft. Consequence & Faith Evans)
songs.title: Stressed Out

description.plain:
“Stressed Out” is the Tribe’s second R&B crossover track, featuring legendary R&B singer Faith Evans singing an interpolation of Anita Baker’s 1988 song “Good Love” on the hook.

The song is the second single off of Beats, Rhymes and Life. The track was remixed countless times and was one of Tribe’s last big tracks. The song’s maxi-single features remixes by Icelandic singer Björk.

songs.full_title: Keep It Rollin' by A Tribe Called Quest (Ft. Large Professor)
songs.title: Keep It Rollin’

description.plain:
Utilizing a sample of the Roy Ayers Ubiquity’s version of “Feel Like Makin' Love,” Tribe connects with producer/MC Large Professor, who at the time was in the midst of separating from his group Main Source, which he alludes to in his verse. Large Pro talked about the track with Complex:


So there was this joint, and I looped it up. And my boy Tony Rome, and Yusef, they had looped it up a while ago, and I was like, ‘Yeah, that shit is hot.’ But I never really knew what it was. But when I threw that record up there, I was like, ‘Oh shit, [I remember this joint].’ Then Tip was like, ‘Yo, that’s dope!’ Then I threw the drums to it, and it was cool.

I didn’t think they were gonna use it. It was crazy. He was like, ‘Yo, I’m in the studio, and I got that joint that you looped up. Come on, let’s rhyme over it.’


The track samples the intro from the Roy Ayers Ubiquity’s 1974 version of “Feel Like Makin' Love”:
https://youtu.be/wMo2nmliHTg

songs.full_title: Rap Promoter by A Tribe Called Quest
songs.title: Rap Promoter

description.plain:
“Rap Promoter,” is a pointed jab at the monetization of rap music in the music industry. Q-Tip warns up-and-coming rappers about venue promoters and their shady tactics of scamming money out of them.

Q-Tip injects his raps with interpolated lines from Peter, Paul & Mary’s “Leaving on a Jet Plane”, as well as Sugar Hill Gang’s “8th Wonder”.

This song’s message is similarly conveyed on “Show Business,”, another track on the album.
